ubuntu has me feeling like I'm back in the Linux community again. :)
it does something in the vein of what you seek for upgrades
highly, highly recommended in addition to apt-listchanges(8)
I just use it to denote what type of program it is; sometimes I use it to denote a man page.
figured that was what you were hinting at ;)
if you're absolutely teeting for it, uupdate & family.
otherwise, wait an afternoon or two and it'll be pulled in.
'uupdate' is part of the 'devscripts' package, which you can use to generate the infrastructure for creating a deb from a new upstream source revision.

time for dinner now.  I'll be back in a bit.  The question I have is, how can I completely purge my kernel and re-install it.  I need to have my kerenl and firmware stuff all back to the original install state.   (I upgraded my wireless firmware -- http://kerneltrap.org/node/5414  {trying to undo all that})
search for any linux-image* and linux-restricted-modules* packages and purge them
occy: search for any linux-image* and linux-restricted-modules* packages and purge them
did you happen to see that?  apt-get --purge linux-image`uname -r` linux-restricted-modules`uname -r`
keep in mind that purging those packages won't erase the directories into which you've installed additional files
I've only done the dpkg -l thingy for now.
didn't want to screw up anything.
you'd have to manually rm -rf those directories in /lib/modules/
what dir did those extra kernel modules install into?
I'm guessing that was the dir.  :/
no way to just purge and then reinstall forcing the original state of things?
I was using a default Ubuntu kernel setup just peachy.
change out of that dir, then sudo aptitude purge linux-restricted-modules-$(uname -r) linux-image-$(uname -r)
was documenting so I can post a mini-howto on my site. ;)
then sudo apt-get --reinstall install linux-image-$(uname -r) linux-restricted-modules-$(uname -r) linux-headers-$(uname -r)
I guess I just need to reboot now?
okies bud.  be back in a bit.
gonna go make a 'tips and tricks' post on http://occy.net/ about it.
I might want to include Reboot to be complete.
thank you again.  I do appreciate all your time and help.
if Breezy is _that_ broken that a new user has a disastrous experience, then that's a critical issue, and testing will help iron that out before the final release.
well, good point but... do we really want to displace advocacy with new users as guinie pigs?

no. When it enters Dapper, it'll be backported to Breezy.

I nukd all my prefs too

you could also be insane and run Dapper like those of us who are insane.
true, it'd probably be no less stable than my setup now.
haven't had any here, but I don't use any extensions
I wonder... maybe it's the stupid web developer plugin

what I did was, I went into synaptic, and nuked all my entries to my sources.list,  and then added each of the binary options and checked all of the available solutions.  then upgraded and things are stable now.
I bet you there are a lot of people who would do what I didn't do.

things got so bad, I nuked my sytem, tried gentoo, tried Suse 10.0, and tried kubuntu.  got fed up and came back to ubuntu and gnome,  figured I'd stick with the bugginess.  But, then I figured that out.  Things have been rock solid for like 4 days.
